author: m.kalinin
content:
FYI, I have recently added `latest_execution_payload_header` to the `BeaconState` API schema in Teku. It only affects endpoints like `/eth/v1/debug/beacon/states/{stateId}` and might be useful for debug purposes. Docker image is also updated. Sorry for late update, I have almost forgot to do that. 

**Note:** If you already have your Teku nodes up and running there is no value in restarting it with a newer version. I'll run latest version and will be able to grab this info if required.

author: m.kalinin
content: I don't think there are any changes on the execution clients side except for bug fixes. So, I'd assume it just works as in the previous run

author: protolambda
content:
<@!553610810652622860> Try add  `--networkid=702` to the geth cli flags. I can't find the config var for the geth chain config for network ID, but `chainId` is configured as 702 at least. And regardless, I don't think the tx pool is enabled in geth catalyst mode yet. 
Also kind of weird: the nethermind/parity style eth1 config uses `networkID` in its params section, to set the chain ID (but it works and is tested).

author: protolambda
content: And in besu it should just correctly default the network ID to the chain ID value. If not, you can override it with `--network-id`

author: protolambda
content: We could try peer the eth1 side later today

author: zahary.
content: The problem for Nimbus in particular is that we have a safety feature that tries to check whether the web3 provider is serving data for the right network (based on the `net_version` result). The build that I prepared yesterday will refuse to connect to a recent Catalyst node launched without overriding the `--networkid` parameter. I'm preparing a new commit for Nimbus now that removes this check for nocturne for now

author: paulhauner
content: We also have this check disabled in LH from a much older iteration of merge testnets.

author: zahary.
content: Fix pushed to `quick-merge-v1`

author: protolambda
content:
Recap, for anyone involved with the devnet:
- It's named "Nocturne", after a rayonist painting. Think of it like dusk, this will be the last devnet. After this we'll continue with sharding and withdrawals prototyping, but move to productionize the Merge spec (transition + new API format, isolated from user JSON-RPC) and work on Altair/London.
- Devnet genesis is tomorrow, noon UTC
- Testnet configs: https://github.com/protolambda/nocturne
- Tutorial to run nodes: https://github.com/protolambda/mergenet-tutorial/
- Fork monitor: https://fork.nocturne.rayonism.io/
- Block explorer: https://nocturne.rayonism.io/   (experimental)
- Ansible for 12 combi setup + explorer + forkmon + etc., for the curious: https://github.com/protolambda/mergenet-ansible/
- Devnet plan:
  - Zoom call ~ 30 min before genesis, no obligations, just fun
  - Check fork monitor and explorer, wait for finality  (if everything goes well, this is super experimental after all...)
  - After at least 30 min of finality, we will try deposits and more advanced transactions
  - <@!755590043632140352> has fun plans to break the devnet. Everyone is welcome to also try, that's what it is for. Just share your plans here before you execute them, so we can debug and improve on whatever is the effect.
  - Eth1 voting will be interesting (vote for its own chain, with 8 hour delay). We expect some issues, but with no bad majority, everything should be fine, and then deposits can be processed.
  - During the devnet, we are testing some modifications to Eth1 clients (e.g. forkchoicer PR in Geth), but no major changes compared to Steklo

author: potuz
content:
Do you guys know if this peer is a crowler? I can't really have debug logs because I am being flooded by these
```
[2021-05-11 17:10:18] DEBUG sync: Could not decode goodbye stream message error=stream reset peer=16Uiu2HAmQpwygp3PMoKH1N4QPVSU2yxxMjYEWrkH7B6VLKkAd28X topic=/eth2/beacon_chain/req/goodbye/1/ssz_snappy
[2021-05-11 17:10:21] DEBUG sync: Invalid status message from peer error=wrong fork digest version handler=status peer=16Uiu2HAmQpwygp3PMoKH1N4QPVSU2yxxMjYEWrkH7B6VLKkAd28X
[2021-05-11 17:10:21] DEBUG sync: Sending Goodbye message to peer Reason=irrelevant network peer=16Uiu2HAmQpwygp3PMoKH1N4QPVSU2yxxMjYEWrkH7B6VLKkAd28X
```
And it's like this several per second until it gets banned and after a few minutes it comes back to flood aggressively.  I wonder if nodes shouldn't just ban immediately a peer with an irrelevant network.

author: protolambda
content: In other news, my lighthouse nodes have 33 peers, and seen 67 different peers so far, not bad for an experimental testnet

author: clefru
content:
<@!203220829473996800> Thanks for merging the PRs in the mergenet-tutorial. In from_docker.md under Prysm, there are two pairs docker images listed, on with merge-mainnet at the end, and one with merge-minimal. The minimal docker image fails to start with the genesis.ssz for nocturne:
```
time="2021-05-11 20:36:00" level=error msg="could not load genesis from file: too big for the list" prefix=main
```
The merge-mainnet image works and my Pyrsm node waits for genesis. Do you know what's the -minimal image for? (Or maybe someone from Pyrsm could answer that). Should we have the -minimal image in the tutorial if it doesn't work with nocturne?

author: protolambda
content: The minimal one is built for a different, more minimal configuration. The state size would also be different (smaller)

author: protolambda
content: hence the decoding error you are seeing

author: protolambda
content: Just use the mainnet one, without the minimal suffix

author: protolambda
content: Or use the image provided by the prysm team

author: clefru
content: Okay thanks for the explanation. The docker example command is using the -minimal image, so I just pasted that to get started.

author: protolambda
content: right, the tutorial walks you through a minimal-config setup for local testing, since you wouldn't want to run 16000+ validators on your computer likely
